snippet: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.
abstract: Sam Borden On Soccer column notes that the United States national soccer team does not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as other World Cup squads, putting them at strategic disadvantage; argues that, for better or worse, playacting is part of the game and has already been a decisive factor in several World Cup matches.
lead_paragraph: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.

headline.main: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Soccer Falls Short
headline.print_headline: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Falls Short

keywords.value: United States Men's National Soccer Team
keywords.name: organizations
